devdoc.para: Specifies what went wrong (or right) during a Message Queuing operation. This is the type of a property of an acknowledgement message.
The default value of the property. This means the message is not an acknowledgment message.

member.name: F:Experimental.System.Messaging.Acknowledgment.AccessDenied
member.devdoc: The sending application does not have access rights to the destination queue.

member.name: F:Experimental.System.Messaging.Acknowledgment.BadDestinationQueue
member.devdoc: The destination queue is not available to the sending application.

member.name: F:Experimental.System.Messaging.Acknowledgment.BadEncryption
member.devdoc: The destination Queue Manager could not decrypt a private (encrypted) message.

member.name: F:Experimental.System.Messaging.Acknowledgment.BadSignature
member.devdoc: MSMQ could not authenticate the original message. The original message's digital signature is not valid.

member.name: F:Experimental.System.Messaging.Acknowledgment.CouldNotEncrypt
member.devdoc: The source Queue Manager could not encrypt a private message.

member.name: F:Experimental.System.Messaging.Acknowledgment.HopCountExceeded
member.devdoc: The original message's hop count is exceeded.

member.name: F:Experimental.System.Messaging.Acknowledgment.NotTransactionalQueue
member.devdoc: A transaction message was sent to a non-transaction queue.

member.name: F:Experimental.System.Messaging.Acknowledgment.NotTransactionalMessage
member.devdoc: A non-transaction message was sent to a transaction queue.

member.name: F:Experimental.System.Messaging.Acknowledgment.Purged
member.devdoc: The message was purged before reaching the destination queue.

member.name: F:Experimental.System.Messaging.Acknowledgment.QueueDeleted
member.devdoc: The queue was deleted before the message could be read from the queue.

member.name: F:Experimental.System.Messaging.Acknowledgment.QueueExceedMaximumSize
member.devdoc: The original message's destination queue is full.

member.name: F:Experimental.System.Messaging.Acknowledgment.QueuePurged
member.devdoc: The queue was purged and the message no longer exists.

member.name: F:Experimental.System.Messaging.Acknowledgment.ReachQueue
member.devdoc: The original message reached its destination queue.

member.name: F:Experimental.System.Messaging.Acknowledgment.ReachQueueTimeout
member.devdoc: Either the time-to-reach-queue or time-to-be-received timer expired before the original message could reach the destination queue.

member.name: F:Experimental.System.Messaging.Acknowledgment.ReceiveTimeout
member.devdoc: The original message was not removed from the queue before its time-to-be-received timer expired.

member.name: F:Experimental.System.Messaging.Acknowledgment.Receive
member.devdoc: The original message was retrieved by the receiving application.

devdoc.para: Specifies what kind of acknowledgment to get after sending a message.
Use this value to request a positive acknowledgment when the message reaches the queue.
Use this value to request a positive acknowledgment when the message is successfully retrieved from the queue.
Use this value to request a negative acknowledgment when the message fails to be retrieved from the queue.
Use this value to request no acknowledgment messages (positive or negative) to be posted.
Use this value to request a negative acknowledgment when the message cannot reach the queue. This can happen when the time-to-reach-queue timer expires, or a message cannot be authenticated.
Use this value to request a negative acknowledgment when an error occurs and the message cannot be retrieved from the queue before its time-to-be-received timer expires.

Use this value to request full acknowledgment (positive or negative) depending on whether or not the message reaches the queue. This can happen when the time-to-reach-queue timer expires, or a message cannot be authenticated.
Use this value to request full acknowledgment (positive or negative) depending on whether or not the message is retrieved from the queue before its time-to-be-received timer expires.
Formatter class that serializes and deserializes primitives, classes, enumeration, and other objects into and from messages using binary format.

member.name: M:Experimental.System.Messaging.ActiveXMessageFormatter.CanRead(Experimental.System.Messaging.Message)
member.devdoc: When this method is called, the formatter will attempt to determine if the contents of the message are something the formatter can deal with.

member.name: M:Experimental.System.Messaging.ActiveXMessageFormatter.Clone
member.devdoc: This method is needed to improve scalability on Receive and ReceiveAsync scenarios. Not requiring thread safety on read and write.

devdoc.para: [To be supplied.]

member.name: M:Experimental.System.Messaging.ActiveXMessageFormatter.Read(Experimental.System.Messaging.Message)
member.devdoc: This method is used to read the contents from the given message and create an object.

member.name: M:Experimental.System.Messaging.ActiveXMessageFormatter.Write(Experimental.System.Messaging.Message,System.Object)
member.devdoc: This method is used to write the given object into the given message. If the formatter cannot understand the given object, an exception is thrown.

member.name: T:Experimental.System.Messaging.CryptographicProviderType
member.devdoc: Typically used when working with foreign queues. The type and name of the cryptographic provider is required to validate the digital signature of a message sent to a foreign queue or messages passed to MSMQ from a foreign queue.

member.name: M:Experimental.System.Messaging.Design.SizeConverter.ConvertTo(System.ComponentModel.ITypeDescriptorContext,System.Globalization.CultureInfo,System.Object,System.Type)
member.devdoc: Converts the given object to another type. The most common types to convert are to and from a string object. The default implementation will make a call to ToString on the object if the object is valid and if the destination type is string. If this cannot convert to the desitnation type, this will throw a NotSupportedException.

devdoc.para: Specifies the encryption algorithm used to encrypt the message body of a private message.
No encryption.

The value MQMSG_CALG_RC2. This is the default value for the property of the Message Queuing application's
object.

The value MQMSG_CALG_RC4. This corresponds to the less secure option for the property of the Message Queuing application's
object.
Specifies the privacy level of messages received by the queue.
Accepts only non-private (non-encrypted) messages.
Does not force privacy. Accepts private (encrypted) messages and non-private (non-encrypted) messages.
Accepts only private (encrypted) messages.

Is required whenever an application sets a message property that is typically set by MSMQ. It is typically used in the following two cases. Whenever a message is passed by a connector application, the connector type is required so that the sending and receiving applications know how to interpret the security and acknowledgment properties of the messages. When sending application-encrypted messages, this property tells the MSMQ run time to use the symmetric key.
Gets or sets the message identifier used by acknowledgment and report messages to reference the original message.

member.devdoc: The default extension buffer size to create, when the message is received.

member.name: P:Experimental.System.Messaging.Message.DefaultLabelSize
member.devdoc: The default label buffer size to create, when the message is received.

devdoc.para: Identifies the original destination queue for a message. It is typically used to determine the original destination of a message that is in a journal or dead-letter queue, however it can also be used when sending a response message back to a response queue.
Gets or sets the symmetric key used to encrypt messages.
Gets or sets the digital signature used to authenticate the message.

Gets or sets additional information associated with the message.

Gets or sets a value indicating whether the message is guaranteed to be delivered in the event of a computer failure or network problem.
Gets or sets the queue which receives application-generated response messages.
Specifies the security certificate used to authenticate messages.

This property is set by MSMQ, and is used primarily by the receiving Queue Manager when authenticating a message. The receiving Queue Manager uses the sender identifier in this property to verify where the message originated and to verify the sender has access rights to a queue.
Gets the version of Message Queuing used to send the message.

Advances the enumerator to the next message in the queue, if one is currently available.
Advances the enumerator to the next message in the queue. If the enumerator is positioned at the end of the queue, waits until a message is available or the given expires.
Removes the current message from the queue and returns the message to the calling application.
Removes the current message from the queue and returns the message to the calling application.
Removes the current message from the queue and returns the message to the calling application.
Removes the current message from the queue and returns the message to the calling application within the timeout specified.
Removes the current message from the queue and returns the message to the calling application within the timeout specified.
Removes the current message from the queue and returns the message to the calling application within the timeout specified.
Resets the current enumerator, so it points to the head of the queue.

member.name: T:Experimental.System.Messaging.MessagePriority
member.devdoc: Message priority effects how MSMQ handles the message while it is in route, as well as where the message is placed in the queue. Higher priority messages are given preference during routing, and inserted toward the front of the queue. Messages with the same priority are placed in the queue according to their arrival time.

member.name: P:Experimental.System.Messaging.MessageQueue.SynchronizingObject
member.devdoc: Represents the object used to marshal the event handler calls issued as a result of a BeginReceive or BeginPeek request into a specific thread. Normally this property will be set when the component is placed inside a control or a from, since those components are bound to a specific thread.

devdoc.para: Gets a value indicating whether the queue supports transactions.
Gets or sets a value indicating whether retrieved messages are copied to the journal queue.
The native handle used to send messages to the message queue
Occurs when a message has been taken out of the queue. This is a result of the asynchronous operation .

Initiates an asynchronous peek operation with no timeout. The method returns immediately, but the asynchronous operation is not completed until the event handler is called. This occurs when a message is available in the queue.

Initiates an asynchronous peek operation with the timeout specified. The method returns immediately, but the asynchronous operation is not completed until the event handler is called. This occurs when either a message is available in the queue or the timeout expires.

Initiates an asynchronous peek operation with a state object that associates information with the operation throughout the operation's lifetime. The method returns immediately, but the asynchronous operation is not completed until the event handler is called. This occurs when either a message is available in the queue or the timeout expires.

Initiates an asynchronous peek operation that receives notification through a callback which identifies the event handling method for the operation. The method returns immediately, but the asynchronous operation is not completed until the event handler is called. This occurs when either a message is available in the queue or the timeout expires.
Receives the first message available in the queue referenced by the .
Receives the first message available in the queue referenced by the . Waits the specified interval for the message to be removed.
Receives the first message available in the queue referenced by the . Waits the specified interval for a new message to be removed and uses the specified object to retrieve the result.

Receives the first message available in the queue referenced by the . Waits the specified interval for a new message to be removed, uses the specified object to retrieve the result, and receives notification through a callback.
[To be supplied.]
Frees all resources allocated by the .
Creates a nontransactional Message Queuing backend queue resource with the specified path.
Creates a transactional or nontransactional Message Queuing backend queue resource with the specified path.
Deletes a queue backend resource identified by the given path.
Completes an asynchronous peek operation associated with the parameter.
Terminates a receive asynchronous operation identified by the specified interface.
Determines whether a queue with the specified path exists.
Returns all the messages available in the queue.

[To be supplied.]

devdoc.para: Returns without removing (peeks) the first message available in the queue referenced by the . This call is synchronous. It blocks the current thread of execution until a message is available.
Returns without removing (peeks) the first message available in the queue referenced by the . Waits the specified interval for a message to become available.
Peeks the message that matches the given ID. If there is no message with a matching ID, an exception will be raised.
Peeks the message that matches the given ID. This method waits until a message with a matching ID is available, or the given timeout expires when no more messages can be inspected.
Peeks the message that matches the given correlation ID. If there is no message with a matching correlation ID, an exception is thrown.

Peeks the message that matches the given correlation ID. This function will wait until a message with a matching correlation ID is available, or the given timeout expires when no more messages can be inspected.
Deletes all the messages contained in the queue.
Receives the first message available in the queue referenced by the . This call is synchronous. It blocks the current thread of execution until a message is available.

devdoc.para: Provides (forward-only) cursor semantics to enumerate the queues on a computer.
devdoc.note: I'm assuming all the queues have to be on the same computer. Is this the case? Do we want to translate this reference to "cursor semantics" into English, or is it okay as it stands? Will the users understand the concept of a cursor?

member.name: P:Experimental.System.Messaging.MessageQueueEnumerator.Current
member.devdoc: Returns the current MessageQueue of the enumeration. Before the first call to MoveNext and following a call to MoveNext that returned false an InvalidOperationException will be thrown. Multiple calls to Current with no intervening calls to MoveNext will return the same MessageQueue object.

devdoc.para: Frees the managed resources associated with the enumerator.
Indicates the native Message Queuing handle used to locate queues in a network. This property is read-only.
Advances the enumerator to the next queue of the enumeration, if one is currently available.
Resets the cursor, so it points to the head of the list..
[To be supplied.]

member.name: F:Experimental.System.Messaging.MessageQueueErrorCode.MessageAlreadyReceived
member.devdoc: A message that is currently pointed at by the cursor has been removed from the queue by another process or by another call to MQReceiveMessage without the use of this cursor.

member.devdoc: The given format name is invalid.

member.devdoc: The RPC server can not impersonate the client application, hence security credentials could not be verified.

member.name: T:Experimental.System.Messaging.XmlMessageFormatter
member.devdoc: Formatter class that serializes and deserializes objects into and from MessageQueue messages using Xml.

member.name: M:Experimental.System.Messaging.XmlMessageFormatter.#ctor
member.devdoc: Creates a new Xml message formatter object.

member.name: M:Experimental.System.Messaging.XmlMessageFormatter.#ctor(System.String[])
member.devdoc: Creates a new Xml message formatter object, using the given properties.

member.name: M:Experimental.System.Messaging.XmlMessageFormatter.#ctor(System.Type[])
member.devdoc: Creates a new Xml message formatter object, using the given properties.

member.name: P:Experimental.System.Messaging.XmlMessageFormatter.TargetTypeNames
member.devdoc: Specifies the set of possible types that will be deserialized by the formatter from the message provided.

member.name: P:Experimental.System.Messaging.XmlMessageFormatter.TargetTypes
member.devdoc: Specifies the set of possible types that will be deserialized by the formatter from the message provided.

member.name: M:Experimental.System.Messaging.XmlMessageFormatter.CanRead(Experimental.System.Messaging.Message)
member.devdoc: When this method is called, the formatter will attempt to determine if the contents of the message are something the formatter can deal with.

member.name: M:Experimental.System.Messaging.XmlMessageFormatter.Clone
member.devdoc: This method is needed to improve scalability on Receive and ReceiveAsync scenarios. Not requiring thread safety on read and write.

member.name: M:Experimental.System.Messaging.XmlMessageFormatter.Read(Experimental.System.Messaging.Message)
member.devdoc: This method is used to read the contents from the given message and create an object.

member.name: M:Experimental.System.Messaging.XmlMessageFormatter.Write(Experimental.System.Messaging.Message,System.Object)
member.devdoc: This method is used to write the given object into the given message. If the formatter cannot understand the given object, an exception is thrown.
